> > Is it so wrong to want to instantiate a test with some parameters and
> > automatically run the tests on it?
> 
> No, but JUnit was not designed that way.

But I keep feeling like there must be a way to get this behaviour out of JUnit
and I am just missing it.  I'm willing to accept that it is a problem with me
rather than JUnit.  Is there something about my outlook on testing that I need
to refine?  I am surprised that data driven testing like this is not supported,
as it seems like soemthign that would be used a lot.  What is the reasoning
behind JUnit not beign designed for this, and is there soemthign that I can do
to acheive what I want while still keeping with JUnit's design goals.

> This is a different problem from the one you described before, so it's a 
> different one from what I tried to help you solve.

Yes, that is why I tried to describe it better.  I really appreciate your taking
the time to understand what I am saying and help me.  I bought your book
yesterday and I plan to read it over the holidays.
Alright I will look into FitNesse like you suggested.  But I still feel like
there is either an issue with JUnit or my understanding of it since I failed to
make this work.

Thanks!! :)

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
subject: Re: [junit] Instantiated TestCase won't run tests
